children.comment: Everything in Dart is an [Object].
children.name: Object

children.comment:
The equality operator.

The default behavior for all [Object]s is to return true if and
only if [:this:] and [other] are the same object.

If a subclass overrides the equality operator it should override
the [hashCode] method as well to maintain consistency.
Returns a string representation of this object.
children.name: toString

children.comment:
[noSuchMethod] is invoked when users invoke a non-existant method
on an object. The name of the method and the arguments of the
invocation are passed to [noSuchMethod] in an [Invocation].
If [noSuchMethod] returns a value, that value becomes the result of
the original invocation.

The default behavior of [noSuchMethod] is to throw a
[noSuchMethodError].
children.name: noSuchMethod

children.comment:
Get a hash code for this object.

All objects have hash codes. Hash codes are guaranteed to be the
same for objects that are equal when compared using the equality
operator [:==:]. Other than that there are no guarantees about
the hash codes. They will not be consistent between runs and
there are no distribution guarantees.

If a subclass overrides [hashCode] it should override the
equality operator as well to maintain consistency.
children.name: hashCode

children.comment: A representation of the runtime type of the object.
children.name: runtimeType

children.comment:
Creates a new [Object] instance.

[Object] instances have no meaningful state, and are only useful
through their identity. An [Object] instance is equal to itself
only.
children.name: Object

children.comment: Keeps {@link Flusher} running.
children.name: Rescuer

children.comment: Calls {@link SchedulerImpl#flushPostEventPumpCommands()}.
children.name: Flusher

children.comment:
Metadata bag for command objects. It's a JSO so that a lightweight JsArray
can be used instead of a Collections type.
children.name: Task

children.comment: Has implicit cast.
children.name: getRepeating

children.comment: Has implicit cast.
children.name: getScheduled

children.comment:
This is used by Scheduler to collaborate with Impl in order to have
FinallyCommands executed.
children.name: SchedulerImpl

children.comment: Provides lazy-init pattern for the task queues.
children.name: _push

children.comment: Extract boilerplate code.
children.name: _createQueue

children.comment: A deferred command is executed after the browser event loop returns.
children.name: scheduleDeferred

children.comment:
An "entry" command will be executed before GWT-generated code is invoked by the browser's event loop. The {@link RepeatingCommand} will be called once per entry from the event loop until false is returned. This type of command is appropriate for instrumentation or code that needs to know when "something happens."

If an entry command schedules another entry command, the second command will be executed before control flow continues to the GWT-generated code.
children.name: scheduleRepeatingEntry

children.comment:
An "entry" command will be executed before GWT-generated code is invoked by the browser's event loop. This type of command is appropriate for code that needs to know when "something happens."

If an entry command schedules another entry command, the second command will be executed before control flow continues to the GWT-generated code.
children.name: scheduleEntry

children.comment:
A "finally" command will be executed before GWT-generated code returns control to the browser's event loop. The {@link RepeatingCommand#execute()} method will be called once per exit to the event loop until false is returned. This type of command is appropriate for instrumentation or cleanup code.

If a finally command schedules another finally command, the second command will be executed before control flow returns to the browser.
children.name: scheduleRepeatingFinally
scheduleFinally

children.comment:
Schedules a repeating command that is scheduled with a constant delay. That is, the next invocation of the command will be scheduled for delayMs milliseconds after the last invocation completes.

For example, assume that a command takes 30ms to run and a 100ms delay is provided. The second invocation of the command will occur at 130ms after the first invocation starts. @param cmd the command to execute @param delayMs the amount of time to wait after one invocation ends before the next invocation
children.name: scheduleFixedDelay
scheduleFixedPeriod

children.comment:
Schedules a repeating command that performs incremental work. This type of
command is encouraged for long-running processes that perform computation
or that manipulate the DOM. The commands in this queue are invoked many
times in rapid succession and are then deferred to allow the browser to
process its event queue.

@param cmd the command to execute
children.name: scheduleIncremental
_runRepeatingTasks

children.comment: Execute a list of Tasks that hold both ScheduledCommands and RepeatingCommands. Any RepeatingCommands in the tasks queue that want to repeat will be pushed onto the rescheduled queue. The contents of tasks may not be altered while this method is executing. @return rescheduled or a newly-allocated array if rescheduled is null.
children.name: _runScheduledTasks

children.comment: The delay between flushing the task queues.
children.name: _FLUSHER_DELAY

children.comment: The delay between checking up on SSW problems.
children.name: _RESCUE_DELAY

children.comment:
The amount of time that we're willing to spend executing
IncrementalCommands.
children.name: _TIME_SLICE

children.comment:
A RepeatingCommand that calls flushPostEventPumpCommands(). It repeats if
there are any outstanding deferred or incremental commands.
children.name: flusher

children.comment:
This provides some backup for the main flusher task in case it gets shut
down by a slow-script warning.
children.name: rescue

children.comment:
Use a GWT.create() here to make it simple to hijack the default
implementation.
children.name: SchedulerImpl.Instance

children.comment:
Adapter of RepeatingCommand calling function in execute method
passed through constructor and return result.
children.name: RepeatingCommandAdapter

children.comment: Returns true if the RepeatingCommand should be invoked again.
children.name: execute

children.comment: General-purpose Command interface for tasks that repeat.
children.name: RepeatingCommand

children.comment: Returns true if the RepeatingCommand should be invoked again.
children.name: execute

children.comment:
Adapter of ScheduledCommand calling function in execute method
passed through constructor.
children.name: ScheduledCommandAdapter

children.comment: Invokes the command.
children.name: execute

children.comment: General-purpose Command interface.
children.name: ScheduledCommand

children.comment: Invokes the command.
children.name: execute

children.comment:
This class provides low-level task scheduling primitives. Any exceptions thrown by the command objects executed by the scheduler will be passed to the {@link GWT.UncaughtExceptionHandler} if one is installed.

NOTE: If you are using a timer to schedule a UI animation, use {@link com.google.gwt.animation.client.AnimationScheduler} instead. The browser can optimize your animation for maximum performance.

@see com.google.gwt.core.client.testing.StubScheduler
children.name: Scheduler

children.comment: Returns the default implementation of the Scheduler API.
children.name: get

children.comment: A deferred command is executed after the browser event loop returns.
children.name: scheduleDeferred

children.comment:
An "entry" command will be executed before GWT-generated code is invoked by the browser's event loop. The {@link RepeatingCommand} will be called once per entry from the event loop until false is returned. This type of command is appropriate for instrumentation or code that needs to know when "something happens."

If an entry command schedules another entry command, the second command will be executed before control flow continues to the GWT-generated code.
children.name: scheduleRepeatingEntry

children.comment:
An "entry" command will be executed before GWT-generated code is invoked by the browser's event loop. This type of command is appropriate for code that needs to know when "something happens."

If an entry command schedules another entry command, the second command will be executed before control flow continues to the GWT-generated code.
children.name: scheduleEntry

children.comment:
A "finally" command will be executed before GWT-generated code returns control to the browser's event loop. The {@link RepeatingCommand#execute()} method will be called once per exit to the event loop until false is returned. This type of command is appropriate for instrumentation or cleanup code.

If a finally command schedules another finally command, the second command will be executed before control flow returns to the browser.
children.name: scheduleRepeatingFinally
scheduleFinally

children.comment:
Schedules a repeating command that is scheduled with a constant delay. That is, the next invocation of the command will be scheduled for delayMs milliseconds after the last invocation completes.

For example, assume that a command takes 30ms to run and a 100ms delay is provided. The second invocation of the command will occur at 130ms after the first invocation starts. @param cmd the command to execute @param delayMs the amount of time to wait after one invocation ends before the next invocation
children.name: scheduleFixedDelay
scheduleFixedPeriod

children.comment:
Schedules a repeating command that performs incremental work. This type of
command is encouraged for long-running processes that perform computation
or that manipulate the DOM. The commands in this queue are invoked many
times in rapid succession and are then deferred to allow the browser to
process its event queue.

@param cmd the command to execute
children.name: scheduleIncremental
